labels.name: editorial
labels.description: A matter that the editors can dispose of without working group consensus

issues.title: Search and Discovery
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting - there was broad agreement in the room that because search and discovery are often intertwined with AI, and because robots.txt also implicates search and discovery, it is important to attempt to address these use cases in our vocabulary.

issues.title: Inference-time preferences
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting -- there was broad support for also defining at least one vocabulary term for inference-time use of content by models. More than one term may be necessary, but the sense of the room was that we should keep this as simple as possible at the first instance.

issues.title: TDM
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting. There was some question of whether it was necessary to define a broad TMD term in the vocabulary, but there was not agreement about removing it.

issues.title: Eurocentricity
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The draft is currently written in a Europe-specific way.

issues.title: Hierarchy
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The proposed vocabulary has nesting / hierarchy - use of one term can imply the use of another. In the Brussels meeting, we discussed that this may not always prove to be the case, but no conclusions were reached.

issues.title: Definitions
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting - the definition of terms like 'AI' need to be examined and potentially refined.

issues.title: Mapping vocabulary to preferences
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting. The vocabulary is abstract; it defines terms (e.g., "X") but does not define how to declare preferences (e.g., "I do not prefer X").

issues.title: Vocabulary interface to preferences
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
Discussed in the Brussels meeting. The vocabulary (even when mapped to preferences; see #7) does not specify how an attachment mechanism should express it. 

Sense of the room in Brussels was that:
* The vocabulary should define an abstract model
* The vocabulary should also define a preferred / recommended mapping to strings (i.e., a serialisation)
* Individual attachment mechanisms can opt into using that serialisation, or may define their own

issues.title: "Good" uses
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
E.g., spam filtering, identifying offensive language

Sense in Brussels was that this would be covered by the legal regime, not vocabulary.

issues.title: "Bad" uses
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
E.g., weapons, biometrics, other uses that content owners may not want to countenance. 

Sense in Brussels was that we will not address this in the first deliverables, but might consider in future extensions.

issues.title: Time preferences are applied
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Content might be gathered a long time before it is used. Which location-based attachment should apply to such content -- that requested at approximately the same time as the content, or the most current document?

issues.title: Identifying the set of relevant attachment mechanisms
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
The architecture we're developing accommodates attachment mechanisms that we define in our "core" documents, as well as future extensions -- including those defined by us and by third parties.

Content providers need to know which attachment mechanisms will be paid attention to, and consumers of preferences need to know which ones they're supposed to check. 

There might be:

* one canonical list (e.g., in our specification or an IANA registry)
* more than one list (e.g., defined per-use-case, such as for crawling-to-train vs inference-time)
* undefined list (e.g., defined by legal authority)

issues.title: Combination
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
In Brussels, a sense emerged that we would only address combination for different preferences for the same content (e.g., robots.txt and HTTP header applied to the same file). We would not address combination of preferences from different sources (e.g., the same image from two different sites).

This should be documented in the applicability statement. We also need to determine the algorithm, e.g.,

* Most restrictive
* Most specific attachment
* Most specific preference

issues.title: Applicability Statement
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: This issue captures potential items to discuss in an applicability statement intended for regulators and other parties using the framework we define.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
- opt-in vs opt-out
- robots time dimension
- disparate assertions from multiple sources
- hosted content
- rightsholder identification
- accessibility, academic / research / spam filters, impact upon other "good" uses
- data protection / privacy
- enforcement / audit
- bot identification / authentication
- TDM is very broad

pulls.title: A better README
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body: @mnot, you probably want to have a say here.  I'll be guided by you here as to whether you want to merge this and fix it up, or whether you want to redo it.
